bestBHT.bht: I will only boast of what Christ has done through me, both in preaching the Gospel and through my actions. The signs and wonders I performed were not just spiritual, but external, miraculous acts. I have fully fulfilled my ministry of spreading the Good News of Christ. I won't dare to claim credit for anything that Christ did not work through me. By both my words and my deeds, I have witnessed the power of God at work in me, bringing others to obedience and faith.

Henry Alford: I will only boast of what Christ has veritably done by me towards the obedience of the Gentiles."
The signs and wonders are not spiritual, but external miraculous acts.
I have fully preached (literally, fulfilled) the Gospel of Christ.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I will not dare to go beyond what Christ hath wrought by me.
Albert Barnes: I should be restrained; I should be afraid to speak, if the thing were not as I have stated.
I do not exaggerate my own success, or claim what others have accomplished.
The 'deeds,' that is, the 'lives' of Christian ministers are often as efficacious in bringing people to Christ as their public ministry.
John Calvin: He proves then by evidences that God by the presence of his power had given a testimony to his preaching, and in a manner sealed his apostleship, so that no one ought to have doubted, but, that he was appointed and sent by the Lord."

In short, he declares that with regard to his teaching as well as his doing, he had such strength and energy in preaching Christ, that it was evidently the wonderful power of God, and that miracles were also added, which were seals to render the evidence more certain."
This is a striking passage respecting the benefit of miracles: they are designed to prepare men to reverence and to obey God.
Philip Schaff: The emphasis rests not on the word Christ, but on the phrase did not work through me; the contrast being, not with what he did of himself, or strictly with what others did, but more exactly with what Christ had wrought through him.
I will speak boldly, have my ground of glorying, only in such things as Christ wrought through me.
By word and deed. This phrase qualifies ‘did work through me,’ etc. ‘Word’ refers to his preaching; ‘deed’ includes all the other labors of his apostolic activity.
Archibald T. Robertson: Any one of those things which Christ did not work through me.
John Gill: What he had wrought, and which he could with good conscience speak of to the honour of Christ, and the glory of his grace, were not wrought by himself, but what Christ wrought by him; he was only the instrument, Christ was the efficient cause.

The Gospel was sent among them, and was blessed unto them, to make them, of disobedient, obedient ones; not to men, but to God; not to magistrates and ministers, though they were taught to be so to both, but to Christ.
The means whereby these persons were brought to the obedience of Christ, and of faith, are by word and deed.
John Wesley: By word — By the power of the Spirit.
By deed — Namely, through "mighty signs and wonders.

I have fully preached the Gospel of Christ. I will not dare to go beyond what Christ hath wrought by me. Any one of those things which Christ did not work through me. By word and deed. The 'deeds,' that is, the 'lives' of Christian ministers are often as efficacious in bringing people to Christ as their public ministry. I will boast only of what Christ has done through me to bring the Gentiles to obedience. The signs and wonders were external miracles, not spiritual. I have fulfilled the Gospel of Christ. I won't go beyond what Christ accomplished through me. By preaching and life, I have spread the message. The lives of ministers can be as effective as their public ministry. Miracles served as evidence of God's power. The Gospel brought obedience to Christ through word and deed, through the Spirit's power and miraculous signs.

I will only boast of what Christ has done through me, both in preaching the Gospel and through my actions. The signs and wonders I performed were not just spiritual, but external, miraculous acts. I have fully fulfilled my ministry of spreading the Good News of Christ. I won't dare to claim credit for anything that Christ did not work through me. By both my words and my deeds, I have witnessed the power of God at work in me, bringing others to obedience and faith.
